text:
The Highway Code applies to England, Scotland, and Wales.
Its primary goal is to promote road safety
The code contains both legal requirements, identified by the words 'MUST' or 'MUST NOT', and advisory rules, identified by Shoud or Shoud not, do or do not.
Failure to comply with legal requirements is a criminal offense, which can lead to fines, penalty points, disqualification, or even prison. Advisory rules can be used in court proceedings to establish liability

A key principle is the "Hierarchy of Road Users," which states that those in charge of vehicles capable of causing the greatest harm bear the greatest responsibility to reduce danger to others. Rule H1: This places the most responsibility on drivers of large vehicles, followed by cars, motorcyclists, cyclists, and horse riders. However, all road users, including pedestrians, have a responsibility for their own safety and the safety of others Rule H2: At a junction, drivers, motorcyclists, and horse riders should give way to pedestrians who are crossing or waiting to cross the road you are turning into or from. You MUST give way to pedestrians on a zebra crossing. Rule H3: Drivers and motorcyclists should not cut across cyclists, horse riders, or horse-drawn vehicles when turning. You should give way to them and should stop and wait for a safe gap if necessary.

elements.text:
Where available, use pavements.
If there is no pavement, walk on the right-hand side of the road to face oncoming traffic.
At night or in poor visibility, wear bright or reflective clothing.
Pedestrians MUST NOT be on motorways except in an emergency.
At junctions, you should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross a road you are turning into or out of.
You MUST give way to pedestrians on a zebra crossing

At night, cycles MUST have a white front light, a red rear light, and a red rear reflector.
Cyclists MUST NOT cycle on a pavement.
You should wear a correctly fitted cycle helmet.
When turning at a junction, you should give way to cyclists going straight ahead and should not cut across them.

Riders and pillion passengers MUST wear a protective helmet that is securely fastened.
Provisional licence holders MUST NOT carry a pillion passenger.
To get a full motorcycle licence, you MUST pass a theory test and a practical test.

Fitness to Drive (Rules 90-96)
Tiredness: Do not begin a journey if you are tired. Plan for a 15-minute break every two hours. If you feel sleepy, stop in a safe place. Eyesight: You MUST be able to read a vehicle number plate from 20 metres. If you need glasses or contact lenses to do this, you MUST wear them at all times while driving. Alcohol & Drugs: You MUST NOT drive if you are over the legal alcohol limit. In England and Wales, the limit is 35 microgrammes per 100ml of breath. In Scotland, it is 22 microgrammes. You MUST NOT drive under the influence of drugs or medicine. This includes illegal drugs and certain medicines that may impair your driving.

Vehicle Condition and Documents (Rules 89, 97 & Annexes)
You MUST ensure your vehicle is roadworthy and complies with all regulations. This includes having working lights, brakes, steering, and tyres with the correct tread depth (a minimum of 1.6mm for cars).

Documents: Licence: You MUST hold a valid licence for the vehicle you are driving. Insurance: You MUST NOT drive a vehicle without at least third-party insurance. MOT: Your vehicle MUST have a valid MOT certificate if it is required.

Signals (Rules 103-112) You should give clear signals in good time before you change direction, stop, or move off. Make sure your signals are not confusing to others and cancel them after use. You MUST obey signals given by police officers, traffic officers, and traffic wardens. The horn MUST NOT be used aggressively or when stationary on the road.
It MUST NOT be used in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am, except when another road user poses a danger.

Speed and Stopping Distances (Rules 124-126) Speed Limits: You MUST NOT exceed the maximum speed limit for the road and your vehicle. For cars on a road with street lighting (unless otherwise signed), the limit is generally 30 mph. Stopping Distances:
Always drive at a speed that allows you to stop well within the distance you can see to be clear. Maintain at least a two-second gap between you and the vehicle in front on fast-moving roads. This gap should be at least doubled on wet roads and increased further on icy roads. Stopping distances can be ten times greater in icy conditions.

Lines and Lane Markings (Rules 127-132)
Double White Lines: Where the line nearest to you is solid, you MUST NOT cross or straddle it, with limited exceptions (e.g., to pass a cyclist travelling at 10 mph or less, or to enter an adjoining property, if safe). Reflective Studs: Red: Mark the left edge of the road. Amber: Mark the central reservation of a dual carriageway or motorway. White: Mark lanes or the middle of the road. Green: Mark the edge of the main carriageway at lay-bys and slip roads.

Mobile Phones and Distractions (Rules 148-150)
You MUST NOT use a hand-held mobile phone or similar device for any purpose while driving or supervising a learner. This applies even when stationary in traffic. Exceptions exist for calling 999 or 112 in a genuine emergency where it is unsafe to stop, or for making a contactless payment at a terminal while the vehicle is stationary.

Overtaking (Rules 162-169) Overtake only when it is safe and legal to do so. Give vulnerable road users like motorcyclists, cyclists, and horse riders at least as much room as you would a car. As a guide, leave at least 1.5 metres when overtaking cyclists. You MUST NOT overtake if it involves crossing a solid white line on your side of the road, or near a pedestrian crossing. Junctions (Rules 170-183) STOP Signs: At a junction with a 'Stop' sign and a solid white line, you MUST stop behind the line and wait for a safe gap. GIVE WAY Signs: You MUST give way to traffic on the main road. Box Junctions: You MUST NOT enter a yellow box junction until your exit road or lane is clear. The only exception is when you want to turn right and are only stopped by oncoming traffic or other vehicles also waiting to turn right. Roundabouts (Rules 184-190) On approaching, you should give priority to traffic coming from your right, unless signs or markings indicate otherwise. Give plenty of room to cyclists and horse riders. Do not attempt to overtake them within their lane on the roundabout. At mini-roundabouts, all vehicles MUST pass around the central markings, except for large vehicles that are physically unable to. Pedestrian Crossings (Rules 191-199) You MUST NOT park on a crossing or on the zig-zag lines. Zebra Crossings: You MUST give way when a pedestrian has moved onto the crossing. You should give way if they are waiting to cross. Pelican Crossings: These have a flashing amber light. When it is flashing, you MUST give way to any pedestrians on the crossing. If it is clear, you may proceed. Puffin and Toucan Crossings: These do not have a flashing amber phase and use a standard red-amber-green light sequence. Parking (Rules 238-252) You MUST NOT wait or park on yellow lines during their hours of operation. Double yellow lines mean no waiting at any time. You MUST NOT park facing against the traffic flow at night. When opening your door, you should use the hand on the opposite side (e.g., left hand for the driver's door). This makes you turn your head and helps you see approaching cyclists or traffic. In London and Scotland, you MUST NOT park on the pavement, with limited exceptions. Elsewhere, you should not do so unless signs permit it. Motorways (Rules 253-274) Prohibited Users: Motorways MUST NOT be used by pedestrians, learner drivers (unless with an approved instructor in a dual-controlled car), motorcycles under 50cc, cyclists, or certain slow-moving vehicles. Joining: Give priority to traffic already on the motorway and match your speed to fit into a safe gap in the left-hand lane. Lane Discipline: Keep to the left lane unless overtaking. Overtaking: Overtake only on the right. Do not overtake on the left. Stopping: You MUST NOT stop on the carriageway, hard shoulder, or slip road except in an emergency. Signals: A red 'X' on a sign above a lane indicates the lane is closed. You MUST NOT drive in a closed lane. Penalties (Annex 5) Points System: Accumulating 12 or more penalty points within a 3-year period MUST result in disqualification for at least 6 months. New Drivers: If you get 6 or more penalty points within two years of passing your first driving test, your licence will be revoked. You will have to reapply for a provisional licence and pass both the theory and practical tests again.
Distance to Stop Line Ahead (100 Yards)

Distance to Stop Line Ahead (100 Yards)
Advance warning of restriction or prohibition ahead
With-flow bus lane ahead which pedal cycles and taxis may also use
Lane designated for use by high occupancy vehicles (HOV)
Vehicles permitted to use an HOV lane ahead
Start of motorway and point from which motorway regulations apply
Appropriate traffic lanes at junction ahead
Traffic on the main carriageway coming from right has priority over joining traffic
Additional traffic joining from left ahead. Traffic on main carriageway has priority over joining traffic from right hand lane of slip road
Traffic in right hand lane of slip road joining the main carriageway has priority over left hand lane
Countdown markers at exit from motorway (each bar represents 100 yards to the exit).
Motorway service area sign showing the operators name
Traffic has priority over oncoming vehicles
Hospital ahead with Accident and Emergency facilities
Area in which cameras are used to enforce traffic regulations
Bus lane on road at junction ahead
Direction Signs on roads and motorways
At a junction leading directly into a motorway (junction number may be shown on a black background)
On approaches to junctions (junction number on black background)
Downward pointing arrows mean Get in lane The left-hand lane leads to a different destination from the other lanes.
The panel with the inclined arrow indicates the destinations which can be reached by leaving the motorway at the next junction
Route confirmatory sign after junction a
On approach to a junction in Wales (bilingual)
Primary route forming part of a ring road
Primary route forming part of a ring road a
Direction to toilets with access for the disabled
Ancient monument in the care of English Heritage
Route for pedal cycles forming part of a network
Direction to camping and caravan site
Recommended route for pedal cycles to place shown
Symbols showing emergency diversion route for motorway and other main road traffic
Symbols showing emergency diversion route for motorway and other main road traffic a
Symbols showing emergency diversion route for motorway and other main road traffic d
Symbols showing emergency diversion route for motorway and other main road traffic e
Temporary lane closure (the number and position of arrows and red bars may be varied according to lanes open and closed)
Slow-moving or stationary works vehicle blocking a traffic lane. Pass in the direction shown by the arrow.
End of road works and any temporary restrictions including speed limits
Signs used on the back of slow-moving or stationary vehicles warning of a lane closed ahead by a works vehicle. There are no cones on the road.
Signs used on the back of slow-moving or stationary vehicles warning of a lane closed ahead by a works vehicle. There are no cones on the road A.
Lane restrictions at road works ahead
One lane crossover at contraflow road works
